properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain continues today. Rain, at times heavy, will continue today before easing to light rain tonight. Total rainfall amounts near 50 mm are expected by this evening. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very warm and humid weather is expected to continue. Time span: continuing through Thursday for most areas and potentially through Friday for the northeast. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 37), except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: much of western, central, eastern and northeastern Newfoundland. ### Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-06-24T23:47:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-24T07:48:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0702971222.2020

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of very warm and humid weather is expected. Time span: continuing through Thursday. Maximum daytime temperatures: 28 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 37), except cooler along parts of the coast. Minimum overnight temperatures: 16 to 18 degrees Celsius. Locations: much of western, central and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Very high temperatures will dominate for the next couple of days. Temperatures are expected to turn cooler Friday as showery weather arrives. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please call HealthLine 811 for advice on health risks, symptoms and precautions associated with heat. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-06-24T17:37:16-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions will be favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Boaters may be caught off guard by strong gusts on smaller bodies of water. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-24T10:13:17-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain continuing tonight. Rain, at times heavy, will continue tonight before easing to light rain Wednesday morning. Rain will linger Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm are expected by Wednesday morning over most areas. Locally higher rainfall amounts over 100 mm are expected as some areas such as Sault Ste. Marie have already reported over 100 mm. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall continuing tonight. Heavy rain will continue tonight into Wednesday. Rain is expected to ease to light rain Wednesday morning. Rain will linger into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are expected by Wednesday evening for areas east of Kapuskasing. Local amounts exceeding 50 mm are also possible in this area. Environment and Climate Change Canada continues to monitor the situation. Rainfall warnings may be issued as necessary. Rainfall warnings are issued when rainfall amounts of 50 mm or more are expected in 24 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 33 are expected for the next 3 days. Warm and humid conditions continue. Time span: today and Thursday. Maximum temperature today: near 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 37). Minimum temperature tonight: near 18 degrees Celsius. Maximum temperature Thursday: near 29 degrees Celsius (Humidex 37). Locations: Prince Edward Island Remarks: Warm weather is expected to continue again tomorrow with temperatures near 29 degrees in the afternoon. Some relief from the heat is possible over western Prince Edward Island on Thursday, but warning criteria is likely to be exceeded again on Thursday in the east. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Smoke is causing poor air quality and reducing visibility. Smoke is expected or occurring. High levels of air pollution are expected today due to smoke from forest fires. The smoke plumes from forest fires in the Chute-des-Passes area may affect neighbouring regions. Air quality could deteriorate if the smoke mixes down to ground level. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors, and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If your home is not air-conditioned, be sure the house doesn't get too warm when doors and windows are closed to keep out smoke. Exposure to too much heat can also result in illness. People with lung diseases, such as asthma and COPD, can be particularly sensitive to air pollution. They will generally experience more serious health effects at lower levels. Pollution can aggravate their diseases, leading to increased medication use, doctor and emergency room visits, and hospital visits. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-06-24T23:44:25-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot and humid for inland areas of Nova Scotia. Time span: today to Thursday. Maximum temperature today: near 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 34 to 36). Minimum temperatures tonight: near 18 Celsius. Maximum temperature Thursday: near 29 degrees Celsius parts of northern region (Humidex 35). Locations: Annapolis Valley through northern Nova Scotia Remarks: hot weather with high humidity is expected to continue today. Some areas may see relief from the heat on Thursday, but warning criteria is expected to be exceeded again on Thursday in Pictou and Antigonish. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
